depth.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: the distance from the top surface of something such as a river or hole to the bottom of it
depth.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: a sea with an average depth of 35 metres
The cave descends to a depth of 340 feet.
Plant the beans at a depth of about six inches.
a channel of two feet in depth
depth.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: the distance from the front to the back of an object
depth.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: The depth of the shelves is about 35 cm.
depth.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: how strong an emotion is or how serious a situation is
depth.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: the depth of public feeling on this issue
People need to realize the depth of the problem.
depth.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: the quality of having a lot of knowledge, understanding, or experience
depth.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: a man of great depth and insight
Sheâ€™s quiet, but perhaps she has hidden depths.
I was impressed by the depth of her knowledge.
depth.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: when a lot of details about a subject are provided or considered
depth.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: Network news coverage often lacks depth.
The subject was discussed in great depth.
